title: Psalms Chapter 116 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 116 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 116 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 116.

questions.question: According to Psalms 116:1, why does the psalmist love the LORD?
options: Because he hath heard my voice and my supplications
Because he gave me wealth and riches
Because he made the heavens and the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Because he hath heard my voice and my supplications
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:1 states, 'I love the LORD, because he hath heard my voice and my supplications.'

questions.question: What does the LORD do in response to the psalmist's voice, according to Psalms 116:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Inclines his ear unto me
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:2 says, 'Because he hath inclined his ear unto me, therefore will I call upon him as long as I live.'

questions.question: What surrounded the psalmist in Psalms 116:3?
options: The sorrows of death and pains of hell
questions.correctAnswer: The sorrows of death and pains of hell
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:3 states, 'The sorrows of death compassed me, and the pains of hell gat hold upon me.'

questions.question: Who does the psalmist call upon for deliverance in Psalms 116:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:4 says, 'Then called I upon the name of the LORD; O LORD, I beseech thee, deliver my soul.'

questions.question: How is the LORD described in Psalms 116:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Gracious, righteous, and merciful
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:5 states, 'Gracious is the LORD, and righteous; yea, our God is merciful.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 116:6, whom does the LORD preserve?
questions.correctAnswer: The simple
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:6 says, 'The LORD preserveth the simple: I was brought low, and he helped me.'

questions.question: What does the psalmist tell his soul to do in Psalms 116:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Return unto thy rest
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:7 states, 'Return unto thy rest, O my soul; for the LORD hath dealt bountifully with thee.'

questions.question: What three things has the LORD delivered the psalmist from, according to Psalms 116:8?
options: My soul from death, mine eyes from tears, and my feet from falling
My enemies from harm, my heart from sorrow, my spirit from fear
My family from famine, my home from destruction, my friends from sickness
My body from weakness, my mind from confusion, my path from darkness
questions.correctAnswer: My soul from death, mine eyes from tears, and my feet from falling
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:8 declares, 'For thou hast delivered my soul from death, mine eyes from tears, and my feet from falling.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 116:9, where will the psalmist walk before the LORD?
options: In the land of the living
questions.correctAnswer: In the land of the living
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:9 says, 'I will walk before the LORD in the land of the living.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 116:11 states, 'All men are liars.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:11 says, 'I said in my haste, All men are liars.'

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask in Psalms 116:12?
options: What shall I render unto the LORD for all his benefits toward me?
Where shall I go from thy spirit?
Who shall separate me from the love of Christ?
How can I repay my enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: What shall I render unto the LORD for all his benefits toward me?
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:12 asks, 'What shall I render unto the LORD for all his benefits toward me?'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 116:13: 'I will take the cup of ______, and call upon the name of the LORD.'
questions.correctAnswer: salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:13 states, 'I will take the cup of salvation, and call upon the name of the LORD.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 116:15 says that the death of the LORD's saints is precious in His sight.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:15 says, 'Precious in the sight of the LORD is the death of his saints.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 116:16, what has the LORD done for the psalmist?
options: Thou hast hidden me from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Thou hast loosed my bonds
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:16 says, 'O LORD, truly I am thy servant... thou hast loosed my bonds.'

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 116:18, the psalmist will pay his vows to the LORD in secret, away from all people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:18 states, 'I will pay my vows unto the LORD now in the presence of all his people,' so it is not in secret.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 116 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 116 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 116, what biblical truth would you share about God's response to our prayers?
options: God listens and inclines His ear to us
God only helps those who are perfect
questions.correctAnswer: God listens and inclines His ear to us
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:1-2 teaches that the Lord hears our voice and inclines His ear to our supplications, encouraging us to call upon Him continually. Verses 4 and 6 also affirm God's gracious help in trouble.

questions.question: How does Psalms 116 describe God's character in relation to those who are suffering?
questions.correctAnswer: Gracious, righteous, and merciful
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explicitly states that the LORD is gracious, righteous, and merciful, showing His compassionate nature towards those who suffer. This is supported by His preservation and help in verse 6.

questions.question: What practical advice does Psalms 116 offer for maintaining spiritual strength during hardship?
options: Return to your rest and trust God's bounty
Ignore your feelings and continue working alone
Only rely on your own wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Return to your rest and trust God's bounty
questions.explanation: Verse 7 encourages the soul to return to rest because the LORD has dealt bountifully, teaching believers to find peace and trust in God’s provision in trials. Verses 8 and 9 also emphasize trusting God for deliverance and walking before Him.

questions.question: In the context of stewardship and gratitude, what question does the psalmist ask God in Psalms 116?
options: What shall I render unto the LORD for all his benefits toward me?
How can I earn more wealth?
When will my prayers be answered?
questions.correctAnswer: What shall I render unto the LORD for all his benefits toward me?
questions.explanation: Verse 12 expresses a heart of gratitude and stewardship by questioning how to properly respond to God's blessings, emphasizing the importance of giving back to God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 116 teach about the importance of public testimony and fellowship in the church?
options: Pay vows and praise God in the presence of all His people
Keep faith private without involving others
Avoid church gatherings to stay holy
questions.correctAnswer: Pay vows and praise God in the presence of all His people
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 18 emphasize fulfilling vows and offering praise publicly among God’s people, highlighting the role of communal worship and accountability.

questions.question: What does Psalms 116 say about the value God places on the death of His saints and how should this affect our view of loss?
options: The death of His saints is precious in His sight
Death separates us from God forever
questions.correctAnswer: The death of His saints is precious in His sight
questions.explanation: Verse 15 reveals that God values the death of His saints highly, encouraging believers to view death with reverence and hope rather than fear.

questions.question: A believer feels trapped by difficulties and asks for encouragement. According to Psalms 116, what can you say about God's help in times of lowliness?
options: God helps those who are brought low
Only the strong receive God’s help
Suffering is a sign of God’s displeasure
questions.correctAnswer: God helps those who are brought low
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states that when the psalmist was brought low, the LORD helped him, teaching that God supports and rescues those in humble or weak conditions.

questions.question: How does Psalms 116 illustrate the relationship between belief and speech in times of trial?
options: Belief leads to speaking out even in affliction
Silence is always better than speaking
Doubt should be hidden from others
questions.correctAnswer: Belief leads to speaking out even in affliction
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states 'I believed, therefore have I spoken,' showing that faith prompts honest expression even amid great affliction, encouraging openness in faith.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 116, the psalmist expresses distrust toward all people during his trials.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 11 reveals the psalmist’s haste to say, 'All men are liars,' reflecting a moment of distrust during trial, which underscores the challenge of maintaining faith in human integrity under pressure.

questions.question: What act of worship involving a 'cup' does Psalms 116 mention as a way to honor God?
options: Taking the cup of salvation and calling upon the name of the LORD
Offering a cup of water to the poor
Pouring wine as a sacrifice for others
questions.correctAnswer: Taking the cup of salvation and calling upon the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 13 symbolizes acceptance of God's salvation and continual prayer, teaching believers to publicly embrace and proclaim their gratitude.

questions.question: How does Psalms 116 encourage believers to view their spiritual obligations before the community?
options: Fulfill vows and offer thanksgiving in the presence of all God's people
Keep spiritual commitments private and hidden
Rely on others to fulfill vows for you
Ignore public worship to focus on personal prayer only
questions.correctAnswer: Fulfill vows and offer thanksgiving in the presence of all God's people
questions.explanation: Verses 14, 17, and 18 stress paying vows and offering thanksgiving publicly, underscoring accountability and communal worship in the life of faith.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 116 describes God as preserving the simple and helping those who are lowly.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 6 clearly states that the LORD preserves the simple and helps those brought low, highlighting God’s care for the humble and vulnerable.

questions.question: According to Psalms 116, what personal confession does the psalmist make about his identity before God?
options: I am thy servant, and the son of thine handmaid
questions.correctAnswer: I am thy servant, and the son of thine handmaid
questions.explanation: Verse 16 confesses the psalmist’s humble position as God's servant, acknowledging dependence and God's deliverance from bonds.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Return unto thy ____, O my soul; for the LORD hath dealt bountifully with thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: rest
questions.explanation: Verse 7 instructs the soul to return to rest, indicating spiritual peace and trust in God's generous dealings.

questions.question: What does Psalms 116 say about walking before the LORD and the land of the living?
options: I will walk before the LORD in the land of the living
I will hide from the LORD
I will avoid the presence of the LORD
I will walk alone without God's guidance
questions.correctAnswer: I will walk before the LORD in the land of the living
questions.explanation: Verse 9 affirms the psalmist's commitment to live in God’s presence and guidance, encouraging believers to remain faithful and obedient.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 116 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 116.

questions.question: What reason does the psalmist give for loving the LORD in Psalms 116:1?
options: Because He hath heard my voice and my supplications
Because He created the heavens and the earth
Because He gave the law to Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Because He hath heard my voice and my supplications
questions.explanation: The psalmist explicitly states in Psalms 116:1 that the love for the LORD is due to Him hearing the voice and supplications, highlighting a personal, relational aspect of God’s providence.

questions.question: In Psalms 116:3, the psalmist mentions being compassed by the sorrows of what?
questions.correctAnswer: Death
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:3 describes the psalmist's distress as being surrounded by the sorrows of death, indicating a deep existential threat and foreshadowing deliverance.

questions.question: Which literary device is most evident in Psalms 116:7, 'Return unto thy rest, O my soul;'?
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: The psalmist is addressing his soul as if it were a person capable of returning to rest, a clear example of personification (Psalms 116:7).

questions.question: What does the psalmist claim the LORD has done for his feet in Psalms 116:8?
options: Guided them on a straight path
questions.correctAnswer: Delivered them from falling
questions.explanation: The psalmist emphasizes God's deliverance in the phrase 'my feet from falling,' signifying physical or spiritual stability (Psalms 116:8).

questions.question: How does Psalms 116:10 reflect the psalmist’s faith during affliction?
options: I believed, therefore have I spoken
I doubted, therefore I remained silent
I questioned, therefore I sought answers
questions.correctAnswer: I believed, therefore have I spoken
questions.explanation: This verse reveals a cause-effect relationship between belief and speech, showing faith sustaining the psalmist amid great affliction (Psalms 116:10).

questions.question: What is the psalmist's response to the question in Psalms 116:12 about what he shall render to the LORD?
options: Taking the cup of salvation and calling upon the LORD
Building a house for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Taking the cup of salvation and calling upon the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:13 answers the rhetorical question in verse 12 by showing a commitment to worship and thanksgiving through the symbolic 'cup of salvation.'

questions.question: The phrase 'precious in the sight of the LORD is the death of his saints' (Psalms 116:15) has what theological implication?
options: God values the death of His faithful servants highly
Death is the end of all hope
Death is a punishment from God
questions.correctAnswer: God values the death of His faithful servants highly
questions.explanation: This verse shows God's special care and value for the death of His saints, implying a redemptive or honoring aspect of death in God's economy (Psalms 116:15).

questions.question: Psalms 116:16 calls the psalmist 'thy servant' and 'son of thine handmaid.' What does this reflect about ancient Near Eastern servitude and covenant relationship?
options: A humble acknowledgment of belonging to God as master
questions.correctAnswer: A humble acknowledgment of belonging to God as master
questions.explanation: The terms illustrate the psalmist’s humble submission and covenantal loyalty to God, consistent with servitude language in the ancient Near East (Psalms 116:16).

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'I will pay my vows unto the LORD' (Psalms 116:14, 18) emphasize in the psalm's structure?
options: A chiastic structure emphasizing vow fulfillment
questions.correctAnswer: A chiastic structure emphasizing vow fulfillment
questions.explanation: The repetition frames the psalm’s conclusion and highlights the importance of fulfilling vows as a response to divine deliverance, illustrating chiasm (Psalms 116:14, 18).

questions.question: How does the concept of 'the cup of salvation' in Psalms 116:13 relate to New Testament imagery?
options: It prefigures the cup Jesus shared at the Last Supper
It refers only to Old Testament sacrificial rites
It is unrelated to later biblical themes
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the cup Jesus shared at the Last Supper
questions.explanation: The 'cup of salvation' is often seen as a typological foreshadowing of the New Testament Eucharist, where Jesus speaks of the cup as His blood of the new covenant.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 116:6 says the LORD helps only the wise and strong, not the simple.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:6 explicitly says 'The LORD preserveth the simple,' indicating God's care for the humble and trusting, not just the wise or strong.

questions.question: In Psalms 116:4, the psalmist calls upon the LORD to deliver from what?
questions.correctAnswer: His soul
questions.explanation: The psalmist pleads for deliverance of his soul, showing a deep, spiritual request for salvation and life (Psalms 116:4).

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 116:9 indicates the psalmist’s intention to live in obedience?
options: I will walk before the LORD in the land of the living
I will sing before the LORD forever
I will flee from the LORD
I will hide my face from the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: I will walk before the LORD in the land of the living
questions.explanation: Walking before the LORD indicates a life of obedience and devotion, as stated in Psalms 116:9.

questions.question: What is the significance of the setting mentioned in Psalms 116:19 for paying vows?
options: The courts of the LORD's house in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The courts of the LORD's house in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The psalmist emphasizes public worship and covenant faithfulness in the sacred space of the temple courts in Jerusalem (Psalms 116:19).

questions.question: How does the psalmist’s statement in Psalms 116:11, 'All men are liars,' reflect his emotional state?
options: It expresses despair and distrust during affliction
It is a doctrinal statement about humanity
It is a joyful proclamation of truth
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses despair and distrust during affliction
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s haste and distress lead to a generalized statement of distrust, reflecting emotional turmoil (Psalms 116:11).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 116 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 116 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 116:1, what is the primary reason the psalmist loves the LORD?
options: Because He hath heard my voice and my supplications
Because He created the heavens and the earth
Because He giveth life and breath
questions.correctAnswer: Because He hath heard my voice and my supplications
questions.explanation: The psalmist explicitly states in Psalms 116:1 that his love for the LORD is grounded in God's attentive hearing of his voice and prayers. This theme is consistent with Isaiah 65:24, Jeremiah 33:3, 1 John 5:14, and Hebrews 4:16, which emphasize God’s readiness to hear and respond to His people.

questions.question: What does Psalms 116:2 reveal about God's character in relation to the psalmist's prayers?
options: He hath inclined his ear unto me
questions.correctAnswer: He hath inclined his ear unto me
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:2 shows the LORD's gracious attentiveness to the psalmist’s prayers by inclining His ear. This reflects God's merciful and responsive nature, in line with Exodus 22:27, 1 Peter 3:12, John 10:27, and Romans 8:26 which affirm God’s attentiveness to His people.

questions.question: In Psalms 116:3, what metaphor is used to describe the psalmist's experience of death and suffering?
options: The sorrows of death compassed me, and the pains of hell gat hold upon me
A shadow of darkness covered my path
I walked through the valley of the shadow of death
Chains of despair bound my soul
questions.correctAnswer: The sorrows of death compassed me, and the pains of hell gat hold upon me
questions.explanation: The psalmist uses vivid metaphors to describe the overwhelming nature of death and suffering in Psalms 116:3. This imagery parallels Isaiah 38:10, Job 10:21-22, Revelation 1:18, and Romans 6:23 which discuss death’s power and the hope in God's salvation.

questions.question: What plea does the psalmist make in Psalms 116:4?
options: O LORD, I beseech thee, deliver my soul
Lead me in the way everlasting
Hide me under the shadow of thy wings
questions.correctAnswer: O LORD, I beseech thee, deliver my soul
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls upon the LORD for deliverance of his soul in Psalms 116:4, reflecting a cry for salvation and rescue from distress. This petition aligns with Psalms 34:17, Romans 10:13, 2 Corinthians 1:10, and Psalm 91:14 where God’s deliverance is affirmed.

questions.question: Which attributes of God are highlighted in Psalms 116:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Gracious, righteous, and merciful
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:5 praises God as gracious, righteous, and merciful. These core attributes are foundational in biblical theology and correspond with Exodus 34:6-7, Nehemiah 9:17, Ephesians 2:4-5, and Titus 3:5 which emphasize God’s grace and justice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 116:7 express the psalmist's inner spiritual state?
options: Return unto thy rest, O my soul; for the LORD hath dealt bountifully with thee
My soul is weary and faint within me
I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills
My heart is steadfast, O God, my heart is steadfast
questions.correctAnswer: Return unto thy rest, O my soul; for the LORD hath dealt bountifully with thee
questions.explanation: In Psalms 116:7, the psalmist encourages his soul to find peace because of God’s generous blessings. This reflects themes of spiritual restoration found in Matthew 11:28, Hebrews 4:10, Isaiah 40:31, and John 14:27 about God's provision of rest.

questions.question: What specific deliverances does the psalmist acknowledge in Psalms 116:8?
options: Delivered my soul from death, mine eyes from tears, and my feet from falling
He healed my wounds and renewed my strength
He led me beside still waters and restored my soul
He delivered me from the hand of the enemy
questions.correctAnswer: Delivered my soul from death, mine eyes from tears, and my feet from falling
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:8 lists specific ways God has delivered the psalmist: preservation from death, comfort from sorrow, and stability in life. This triad of salvation corresponds with Isaiah 38:16, John 11:25-26, 2 Corinthians 1:3-4, and Psalm 37:23-24.

questions.question: According to Psalms 116:10, what was the psalmist's response in the midst of great affliction?
options: I believed, therefore have I spoken
I remained silent before the LORD
I questioned the justice of God
questions.correctAnswer: I believed, therefore have I spoken
questions.explanation: The psalmist affirms in Psalms 116:10 that belief in God’s faithfulness prompted him to speak even amidst affliction. This links to Hebrews 11:1, Romans 4:20-21, James 1:2-3, and 2 Corinthians 12:9 which emphasize faith’s role in perseverance.

questions.question: What is the question posed by the psalmist in Psalms 116:12 that relates to responding to God's benefits?
options: What shall I render unto the LORD for all his benefits toward me?
How shall I praise the LORD for His goodness?
Who can understand the greatness of God’s mercy?
Where shall I go from thy Spirit?
questions.correctAnswer: What shall I render unto the LORD for all his benefits toward me?
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:12 poses a reflective question about the appropriate human response to God's benefits, highlighting gratitude and worship. This is echoed in Psalm 50:14, Romans 12:1, Hebrews 13:15, and 1 Thessalonians 5:18.

questions.question: In Psalms 116:13, what is the 'cup' that the psalmist says he will take, and what does it symbolize?
options: The cup of salvation, symbolizing thanksgiving and deliverance
The cup of wrath, symbolizing judgment
The cup of bitterness, symbolizing suffering
The cup of joy, symbolizing celebration
questions.correctAnswer: The cup of salvation, symbolizing thanksgiving and deliverance
questions.explanation: The 'cup of salvation' in Psalms 116:13 symbolizes the psalmist’s acceptance of God's deliverance and a commitment to praise Him. It parallels the Messianic use of 'cup' in Psalm 75:8, Luke 22:20, 1 Corinthians 10:16, and Hebrews 9:15 as emblematic of salvation and covenant.

questions.question: What vow does the psalmist declare he will fulfill in Psalms 116:14?
options: I will pay my vows unto the LORD now in the presence of all his people
I will build a house for the LORD
I will offer a burnt offering of praise
I will proclaim the righteousness of God
questions.correctAnswer: I will pay my vows unto the LORD now in the presence of all his people
questions.explanation: The psalmist commits in Psalms 116:14 to fulfill his vows publicly before God’s people, indicating accountability and corporate worship. This reflects the biblical principle of vow-keeping found in Numbers 30:2, Ecclesiastes 5:4-5, Deuteronomy 23:21, and Matthew 5:33-37.

questions.question: According to Psalms 116:15, how does the LORD regard the death of His saints?
options: Precious in the sight of the LORD
A moment of sorrow and loss
questions.correctAnswer: Precious in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:15 states that the death of the LORD’s saints is precious to Him, affirming the value and honor God places on His faithful. This aligns with Ecclesiastes 3:2, Revelation 14:13, John 14:1-3, and 2 Corinthians 5:8 which portray death as a transition to eternal life.

questions.question: How does the psalmist identify himself in Psalms 116:16 in relation to the LORD?
options: Thy servant, and the son of thine handmaid
questions.correctAnswer: Thy servant, and the son of thine handmaid
questions.explanation: In Psalms 116:16, the psalmist humbly acknowledges his position as the LORD’s servant and son of His handmaid, indicating submission and covenant relationship. This is consistent with Exodus 21:5, Isaiah 41:8, Romans 6:16, and Philippians 1:1 emphasizing servanthood to God.

questions.question: What kind of sacrifice does the psalmist promise to offer according to Psalms 116:17?
questions.correctAnswer: The sacrifice of thanksgiving
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:17 expresses the psalmist’s intention to offer thanksgiving as a sacrifice, emphasizing gratitude over ritual. This corresponds with Hebrews 13:15, Psalm 50:14, 1 Thessalonians 5:18, and Philippians 4:6 that highlight thankful praise as true worship.

questions.question: Where does Psalms 116:19 say the psalmist will pay his vows?
options: In the courts of the LORD'S house, in the midst of Jerusalem
On the mountain of the LORD
At the gates of the city
questions.correctAnswer: In the courts of the LORD'S house, in the midst of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Psalms 116:19 specifies that vows will be fulfilled in the temple courts in Jerusalem, highlighting the central place of worship and community in covenant faithfulness. This fits with Deuteronomy 12:5, 2 Chronicles 7:12-16, Ezra 3:8, and John 2:19-21 regarding the temple as God’s dwelling.
